Award.AbstractNarration:
The AIM Research Conference Center (ARCC) will continue to foster progress in the mathematical sciences through the sponsorship of focused workshops. ARCC workshops are distinguished by their emphasis on a specific mathematical goal, such as a significant unsolved problem, an important new result, or the explanation of the convergence between two distinct areas of mathematics. Central to each workshop is a public website which will outline the scope of the workshop and provide resources for the participants. Following the workshop, the website will be expanded to serve as both a record of the workshop and as a comprehensive resource for the current status of important problems and results. ARCC will also host a sequence of Structured Quartet Research Ensembles during this award. These ensembles are vertically integrated teams of 4 to 8 researchers who work at AIM for one to four weeks on a focused research project.

Mathematics has become an increasingly collaborative endeavor, and many of today's unsolved problems will require techniques from several areas of the mathematical sciences. The ARCC workshops are an ideal forum for teams of researchers to construct a framework for progress on important problems. To ensure that these collaborations will be successful, the leaders in each field will be involved in the planning of the workshops. Equally important is the active involvement of junior scientists and graduate students in the workshops. Special attention is paid to facilitating those collaborations which include women, minorities, and researchers at primarily undergraduate institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this award, the American Institute of Mathematics (AIM) hosted 98 workshops and 71 SQuaREs. AIM workshops, which are five days long with 28 participants, seek to advance a particular subject in a strong way. At each workshop, specific activities identify the key topics which will initiate the greatest progress in the field. Then small groups begin to work collaboratively on some of these problems. Amongst the participants of each workshop are 21 individuals invited by the organizers at the time the workshop is announced along with 7others who are invited through the open application process.


In addition to a publicly-posted problem list each workshop initiates an average of 3 lasting new collaborations and leads to approximately 3 published papers. AIM has designed a particular workshop format that is conducive for discussions, the enunciation of well-posed problems, and the formation of small groups that initiate their collaboration at the workshop.The basic workshop format which precipitates this set of activities is: two highly interactive talks of an introductory nature each morning (designed to prepare the group for afternoon sessions) followed by an afternoon of group work. Typical afternoons include moderated problem sessions, ask-the-experts sessions, small group collaborations, and reporting from small groups.

Workshops are selected by the AIM ScientificBoard which meets the first Saturday in December to review an average of 35 proposals. Roughly 2/3 of AIM workshops fall into a category of fundamental mathematical research and 1/3 may be classified as interdisciplinary research.


The SQuaRes program, which started with this grant, supports groups of 4 to 6 researchers as they undertake an ambitious project. They meet for 5 days at AIM, then return a second and usually a third time at one year intervals for additional 5-day meetings. Each SQuaRE week produces, on average, one paper.


To give some idea of the scope of AIM workshops, here is a sample of someof the titles of workshops during one year of the grant: Small Ball Inequalities in Analysis, Probability, and Irregularities of Distribution; Higher Reidemeister Torsion; Contact Topology and Knots; Combinatorial Challenges in Toric Varieties; The 3D Euler and 2D Surface Quasi Geostrophic Equations; Topological Complexity of Random Sets; Stochastic and Deterministic Modeling of Spatial Dynamic Population Phenomena; Relative Trace Formula and Periods of Automorphic Forms; Analytic Theory of GL3 Automorphic Forms and Applications; The Isoperimetric Inequality for SL(n;Z);  Nonnegative Matrix Theory: Generalizations and Applications; Volume Entropy Rigidity; Frames for the Finite World: Sampling, Coding and Quantization;  Research Experiences in Linear Algebra, and Number Theory for Undergraduate Faculty.
